titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mason Fitch Cogswell Papers
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 04:24

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers primarily consist of correspondence received by Mason Fitch Cogswell from family, friends, and professional colleagues. Prominent among the correspondents are Cogswell's brother Samuel Cogswell, his nephew James Lloyd Cogswell of Long Island, New York, his friend Theodore Dwight, the Caribbean planter Charles Joseph Sibert, Vicomte de Cornillon, and deaf education pioneers Laurent Clerc and T. H. Gallaudet. Other colleagues in the papers are the Reverend Ebenezer Fitch, Connecticut congressman John Davenport, inventor Apollos Kinsley, and a number of American physicians including Oliver Fisk of Worcester, Henry Fish and E. H. Smith of New York, and Joseph Strong of Philadelphia. Notably, there are several letters from Cogswell's many female friends such as Nancy Roy Fox and Delia Dwight Porter. Also in the correspondence is a fair copy of a letter to Cogswell's father James Cogswell from British author William Cowper. Other papers include two diaries kept by Cogswell in 1788 and 1791, financial and legal papers, and a group of manuscript medical remedies and treatments.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Grace Cogswell Root, 1925 and 1926. One diary was the gift of the Misses Tully, 1896.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Mason Fitch Cogswell Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mason Fitch Cogswell Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Mason Fitch Cogswell's 1788 diary is available on microfilm (MS Vault film 1713)

bioghist.head: Mason Fitch Cogswell (1761-1830)
bioghist.p: Mason Fitch Cogswell, an American physician and surgeon, was born on September 28, 1761, in Canterbury, Connecticut, the third son of the Reverend James and Alice Fitch Cogswell. An 1780 graduate of Yale College, he studied medicine with his brother James Cogswell, first in Stamford, Connecticut, and later in New York City. In 1789, Cogswell established a medical office in Hartford, where he practiced until his death in 1830.

Cogswell and his wife Mary Austin Ledyard Cogswell had five children including their daughter Alice, who became deaf as a child. In an effort to educate her and other deaf residents of the state, Cogswell enlisted the aid of Laurent Clerc and Thomas H. Gallaudet to establish in 1817 in Hartford the Connecticut Asylum for the Education and Instruction of Deaf and Dumb Persons, now the American School for the Deaf, the country's first permanent school for the deaf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers primarily consist of correspondence received by Mason Fitch Cogswell from family, friends, and professional colleagues. Prominent among the correspondents are Cogswell's brother Samuel Cogswell, his nephew James Lloyd Cogswell of Long Island, New York, his friend Theodore Dwight, the Caribbean planter Charles Joseph Sibert, Vicomte de Cornillon, and deaf education pioneers Laurent Clerc and T. H. Gallaudet. Other colleagues in the papers are Reverend Ebenezer Fitch, Connecticut congressman John Davenport, inventor Apollos Kinsley, and a number of American physicians including Oliver Fisk of Worcester, Henry Fish and E. H. Smith of New York, and Joseph Strong of Philadelphia. Notably, there are several letters from Cogswell's many female friends such as Nancy Roy Fox and Delia Dwight Porter. Also in the correspondence is a fair copy of a letter to Cogswell's father James Cogswell from British author William Cowper. Other papers include two diaries kept by Cogswell in 1788 and 1791, financial and legal papers, and a group of manuscript medical remedies and treatments. Accompanying the papers are a group of printed items.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1772-1830. II. Writings, 1788-1853. III. Other Papers, 1783-1830.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Family, and Colleagues and Friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I primarily contains letters sent to Cogswell by his family, medical colleagues in several cities and towns, and a variety of friends. The first subseries, family correspondence, holds more than thirty letters from Cogswell to his father James, and over fifty letters from Cogswell's younger brother Samuel, who died tragically at age 36; also in the subseries are letters from the Reverend Ebenezer Fitch, a cousin who married Samuel's widow Maria and raised their three children. Also in the subseries is a fair copy of a letter to James Cogswell from the British author William Cowper.

The second subseries holds letters from Cogswell's friends and peers. Notable among them is his friend Theodore Dwight, a lawyer and publisher, who signed his letters "Orlando," and Charles Joseph Sibert, Vicomte de Cornillon, a planter from Santo Domingo. When letters from Cogswell are present, they are noted at the folder level; at the end of the series is a folder holding copies of other outgoing letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains two autograph manuscript diaries kept by Mason Fitch Cogswell, including one written during a trip from Hartford to New York, returning to Stamford, Connecticut. Also present are a variety of writings in various hands, some likely by Cogswell. The latest item in the Cogswell papers is filed here, a transcript of a song sung at a Yale College event in 1853 by the Class of 1854; this item was owned by Cogswell's grandson Lewis Ledyard Weld. The donors of second diary were likely the daughters of Dr. William Tully, who had studied medicine under Cogswell.

did.unittitle: Diary, November 14-December 20, 1788, with a later transcription by Mary Ledyard Cogswell

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The provenance of this diary is discussed in The Cogswells in America , by E. O. Jameson (1884), pages 245-46.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds financial, legal, and medical papers, including remedies and treatments for cancer and other diseases collected by Cogswell. Two folders at the end of the series hold printed documents including two copies of a 1793 printed form issued by Norwich, Connecticut, publisher Bushnell & Hubbard, seeking subscribers for two proposed books by Michael Martel, The French Scholar's Diversion, and Martel's Virgil . The forms were signed by several residents of Hartford, New London, and other towns in Connecticut, but the volumes were never published.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes Constitution of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences (1800); membership letter from Academy of Medicine of Philadelphia, signed by Philip Syng Physick (1800); report of the Boston Medical Society (1810); and Scheme of the Exercises at the Exhibition of the Brothers' Society, Yale College (December 31, 1817)

did.unittitle: Subscription forms for Michael Martel publications
